author: Cobra Commander

text: If there's one thing to remember 1987 for in terms of video games, it's not the quality of any of the games that were released, but how Mega Man graced us with this box art. Nothing else matters in comparison. Seriously though, Inafune actually attributed this game's bad sales in North America to this box art, not only because the art is ugly, but because it absolutely doesn't represent what's in the game. Mega Man 2 really is what propulsed the series financially. Still, Mega Man was a quality game and Capcom's first real foray into the console market as all of their previous releases were Arcade ports. The game's cartoony graphics with its big sprites were super refreshing back then and the gameplay was top notch, so much so that Capcom stuck with it for all its 8-bit sequels (MM9 and 10 included). I believe this was also the first game to feature stages that you could select and play in any order you want. Hopefully this series is revived one day, it's too much of a shame.
author: SupraDarky

text:
1. Mega Man 11 is already out. 
2. Who on earth hired that guy to design this cover art, not letting him know what the game looks like and not giving enough time?! Wasn't that way too risky if Capcom wanted their game outside of Japan?
3. Changing the name of Rockman to Mega Man was totally redundant. Rockman sounds even better and it's so good that there was no need to westernize the name of the protagonist.
